q2.description: $\textbf {Derivation Trees}$ (also known as 'parse trees'): A derivation tree represents a derivation, but does not show the order in which productions were applied.
q2.question: How many ways that we can use to represent string derivations from grammars?

q3.description: A derivation tree for $G=(V,T,S,P)$ is built by setting the root node label to be $S$
q3.question: The reason for that is we always start deriving a string from the grammar start variable

q4.description:
A derivation tree for $G=(V,T,S,P)$ is built by setting the root node label to be $S$
The clidren of a node will be the RHS of the production rule that we need to use to derive the string.
q4.question: The children for any node can be variables and/or terminals

q5.description:
A derivation tree for $G=(V,T,S,P)$ is built by setting the root node label to be $S$
The clidren of a node will be the RHS of the production rule that we need to use to derive the string.
leaves are labeled $x$, where $x\in T\cup \{\lambda \}$
q5.question: The leaves nodes can be variables and/or terminals

q6.description:
A derivation tree for $G=(V,T,S,P)$ is built by setting the root node label to be $S$
The clidren of a node will be the RHS of the production rule that we need to use to derive the string.
leaves are labeled $x$, where $x\in T\cup \{\lambda \}$
Nonleaf vertices labeled $A$, where $A\in V$
q6.question: The non-leaves nodes will be variables

q9.description:
$\textbf{Definitions:}$ Partial derivation tree is a subtree of a derivation tree.
If partial derivation tree has root $S$ then it represents a sentential form
q9.question: What is the sentential form equivalent to the partial derivation tree on the left?

q10.description:
$\textbf{Definitions:}$ Partial derivation tree is a subtree of a derivation tree.
If partial derivation tree has root $S$ then it represents a sentential form. Leaves from left to right in a derivation tree form the yield of the tree.
q10.question: What is the yield for the partial derivation tree on the left?

q13.description:
$\textbf{Definitions:}$ Partial derivation tree is a subtree of a derivation tree.
If partial derivation tree has root $S$ then it represents a sentential form. Leaves from left to right in a derivation tree form the yield of the tree.
If $w$ is the yield of a derivation tree, then it must be that $w\in L(G)$.
q13.question: Since the string $aac$ is the yield of the tree, then $aac \in L(G)$
